close_symbols: POSIX_GlobalVars (struct/variable) -- at least fields: PageSize, EnableTaskPriorities, SelectedRtScheduler
explanation: OS_PriorityRemap: Need the function prototype/definition to determine how the parameter 'priority' is passed (by value or by pointer). If OS_PriorityRemap took a pointer and modified the caller's object, it could imply modification of the parameter object — relevant to MISRA's allowance for modifying objects pointed-to vs. modifying the parameter itself. PTHREAD_STACK_MIN: Macro/constant definition to confirm it is a simple compile-time constant (not a macro that has side effects) so the 'if (stacksz < PTHREAD_STACK_MIN)' check does not hide any implicit modification of the parameter. POSIX_GlobalVars (PageSize, EnableTaskPriorities, SelectedRtScheduler): The code uses POSIX_GlobalVars.PageSize to compute and change 'stacksz' and reads EnableTaskPriorities/SelectedRtScheduler; the definition/type confirms these are simple global fields (no macros or accessor functions that could alias or modify parameters) and clarifies whether PageSize usage could be a macro/function that mutates stacksz indirectly. pthread_create (prototype): To confirm that passing 'pthr' to pthread_create can legally result in modification of *pthr (the object pointed to) while not modifying the pointer variable 'pthr' itself; MISRA allows modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter but forbids modifying the pointer parameter variable. pthread_t (typedef): To understand the pointer semantics of 'pthread_t *pthr' (i.e., that pthr is a pointer parameter and that pthread_create will write the thread id into *pthr, which is permitted). PthreadFuncPtr_t (typedef): To confirm 'entry' is a function-pointer parameter (and passed to pthread_create) and that no code in this function assigns to the parameter variable itself. osal_priority_t (typedef): To confirm the type/category of the 'priority' parameter (value vs. possibly an alias to a pointer type) so it is clear whether assigning to or passing it could modify the caller's object. These symbols together let an analyst decide whether the function modifies its parameters (the parameter variables themselves) versus modifying objects they point to, and whether any macros or called routines could indirectly alter the parameter variables — the core concern of the MISRA rule.
